This example features how to use chakra-ui as the component library within a Next.js app with typescript.
Next.js and chakra-ui have built-in TypeScript declarations, so we'll get autocompletion for their modules straight away.
We are connecting the Next.js _app.js with chakra-ui's Provider and theme so the pages can have app-wide dark/light mode. We are also creating some components which shows the usage of chakra-ui's style props.

Do anything necessary to build a next.js 15 application which uses react 19.  
Make sure it‚Äôs using npx create scripts and then sets up a basic landing page with 10 sections.  
  
Include chakraui or whatever that ones called. Also include storybook. Only include elements you actually need.

permissions

Okay, let me tackle this step by step. The user wants a Next.js 15 app with React 19, using npx create scripts and Storybook. They also want a landing page with 10 sections and Chakra UI.

First, I need to check if React 19 is compatible with Next.js 15. From the context, there's a mention of ReactJS 19 with Next.js in one of the sources. So, I can use npx create-next-app@latest for Next.js 15.

Next, integrate Chakra UI. The context shows how to install Chakra UI with Next.js using @chakra-ui/react and other dependencies. Also, Storybook setup steps are in the context, using @storybook/nextjs.

project and open it in your favorite editor.$ cd nextjs-for-production~/dev/nextjs-for-production (main) ü§Ø$ cursor .Run The Development ServerYou want to verify that your setup worked.Run npm run dev to start the development server.Visit http://localhost:3000 to view your application.Type Checks With TypeScriptYour project has TypeScript already configured, but you also want to add an explicit command to your package.json that checks all your files for type errors."type-check": "tsc -b"You‚Äôre going to use this command later together with other automated static analysis checks.Code FormattingWhen you collaborate with a large team on a project, it‚Äôs important to unify the way that everyone writes code. that: Prettier and ESLint.PrettierPrettier is an opinionated code formatter that eliminates style discussions during code reviews.Install Prettier together with its Tailwind plugin.npm install --save-dev prettier prettier-plugin-tailwindcssCreate aprettier.config.js file with your preferred rules.module.exports = {  arrowParens: 'avoid',  bracketSameLine: false,  bracketSpacing: true,  htmlWhitespaceSensitivity: 'css',  insertPragma: false,  jsxSingleQuote: false,  plugins: ['prettier-plugin-tailwindcss'],  printWidth: 80,  proseWrap: 'always',  quoteProps: 'as-needed',  requirePragma: false,  semi: true,  singleQuote: true,  tabWidth: 2,  trailingComma: 'all',  useTabs: false,};Add a formatting script to your package.json."format": "prettier --write .",Run the formatter to apply your style.$ npm run format> nextjs-for-production@0.1.0 format> prettier --write .next.config.mjs 4ms (unchanged)package-lock.json 54ms (unchanged)package.json 1ms (unchanged)postcss.config.mjs 2ms

But here are the steps real quick for your convenience.To set up a database in your Vercel project, follow these steps:Go to the Storage tab and click the Create Database button.When the Browse Storage modal opens, choose Postgres and click Continue.For creating a new database:In the dialog box, type

modal opens, choose Postgres and click Continue.For creating a new database:In the dialog box, type sample_postgres_db (or a name you prefer) in the Store Name field. Ensure the name has only alphanumeric characters, "_" or "-", and does not exceed 32 characters.Choose a region. For lower latency, select a region close to your function region, which is US East by default.Click Create.Then you‚Äôll need to add POSTGRES_URL_NON_POOLING to the datasource in your Prisma schema.datasource db {  provider  = "postgresql"  // Uses connection pooling  url       = env("DATABASE_URL")  // Uses direct connection, ‚ö†Ô∏è make sure to keep this to `POSTGRES_URL_NON_POOLING`  // or you'll have dangling databases from migrations  directUrl = env("POSTGRES_URL_NON_POOLING")}Vercel uses connection poolers, which manage a pool of database connections that can be reused by different parts of an application, rather than establishing a new connection for each database request. The directUrl property is used to

than establishing a new connection for each database request. The directUrl property is used to ensure operations requiring direct database access, such as migrations, can bypass the connection pooler for reliable execution.You can get the environment variables for your Vercel database by pulling them from Vercel.vercel env pull .envPlaywrightYou also want to use E2E tests because E2E tests give you the most confidence that your app works as intended. E2E tests are skipped far too often, but you really should make it a habit to write them. The benefits are compounding.Initialize Playwright.$ npm init playwright@latestGetting started with writing end-to-end tests with Playwright:Initializing project in '.'‚úî Where to put your end-to-end tests? ¬∑ playwright‚úî Add a GitHub Actions workflow? (y/N) ¬∑ false‚úî Install Playwright browsers (can be done manually via 'npx playwright install')? (Y/n) ¬∑ trueIf this is your first time using Playwright, you can have a look through the test-examples/

¬∑ trueIf this is your first time using Playwright, you can have a look through the test-examples/ folder that the initialization script creates, and then deleted it because you won't need it.Modify the webServer key in your playwright.config.ts file.webServer: {  command: process.env.CI ? 'npm run build && npm run start' : 'npm run dev',  port: 3000,},Add two scripts for your E2E tests to your package.json."test:e2e": "npx playwright test","test:e2e:ui": "npx playwright test --ui",The first one runs your Playwright test in headless mode, while the second one runs your test in UI mode, which gives you time travel debugging, watch mode and more.import { expect, test } from '@playwright/test';test.describe('landing page', () => {  test('given any user: shows the test user', async ({ page }) => {    await page.goto('/');    await expect(page.getByText('Jan Hesters')).toBeVisible();    await expect(page.getByText('jan@reactsquad.io')).toBeVisible();  });});Run your tests to check that your

expect(page.getByText('jan@reactsquad.io')).toBeVisible();  });});Run your tests to check that your Playwright setup worked.$ npm run test:e2e> reactsquad-production@0.1.0 test:e2e> npx playwright testRunning 3 tests using 3 workers  3 passed (3.9s)It ran three tests because by default Playwright is configured to run in Chrome, Safari, and Firefox.GitHub ActionsIt‚Äôs good practice to run your app with CI/CD. CI/CD stands for continuous delivery and continuous deployment.Add a secret for your database URL to your repository‚Äôs settings in GitHub.DATABASE_URL="postgresql://postgres:postgres@localhost:5432/testdb"Then create your GitHub Actions YAML configuration in a .github/workflows/pull-request.yml file for a comprehensive CI/CD pipeline including linting, type checking, testing, and more.name: Pull Requeston: [pull_request]jobs:  lint:    name: ‚¨£ ESLint    runs-on: ubuntu-latest    steps:      - name: ‚¨áÔ∏è Checkout repo        uses: actions/checkout@v3      - name: ‚éî Setup node

- name: ‚¨áÔ∏è Checkout repo        uses: actions/checkout@v3      - name: ‚éî Setup node        uses: actions/setup-node@v3        with:          node-version: 20      - name: üì• Download deps        uses: bahmutov/npm-install@v1      - name: üî¨ Lint        run: npm run lint  type-check:    name:  ¶ TypeScript    runs-on: ubuntu-latest    steps:      - name: ‚¨áÔ∏è Checkout repo        uses: actions/checkout@v3      - name: ‚éî Setup node        uses: actions/setup-node@v3        with:          node-version: 20      - name: üì• Download deps        uses: bahmutov/npm-install@v1      - name: üîé Type check        run: npm run type-check --if-present  commitlint:    name: ‚öôÔ∏è commitlint    runs-on: ubuntu-latest    if: github.actor != 'dependabot[bot]'    env:      GITHUB_TOKEN: ${{ secrets.GITHUB_TOKEN }}    steps:      - name: ‚¨áÔ∏è Checkout repo        uses: actions/checkout@v3        with:          fetch-depth: 0      - name: ‚öôÔ∏è commitlint        uses: wagoid/commitlint-github-action@v4  vitest:

0      - name: ‚öôÔ∏è commitlint        uses: wagoid/commitlint-github-action@v4  vitest:    name: ‚ö° Vitest    runs-on: ubuntu-latest    services:      postgres:        image: postgres:12        env:          POSTGRES_USER: postgres          POSTGRES_PASSWORD: postgres          POSTGRES_DB: testdb        ports:          - 5432:5432    steps:      - name: ‚¨áÔ∏è Checkout repo        uses: actions/checkout@v3      - name: ‚éî Setup node        uses: actions/setup-node@v3        with:          node-version: 20      - name: üì• Download deps        uses: bahmutov/npm-install@v1      - name: üõ† Setup Database        run: npm run prisma:wipe        env:          DATABASE_URL: postgresql://postgres:postgres@localhost:5432/testdb      - name: ‚ö° Run vitest        run: npm run test -- --coverage        env:          DATABASE_URL: postgresql://postgres:postgres@localhost:5432/testdb  playwright:    name: üé≠ Playwright    runs-on: ubuntu-latest    services:      postgres:        image: postgres:12        env:

runs-on: ubuntu-latest    services:      postgres:        image: postgres:12        env:          POSTGRES_USER: postgres          POSTGRES_PASSWORD: postgres          POSTGRES_DB: testdb        ports:          - 5432:5432    steps:      - name: ‚¨áÔ∏è Checkout repo        uses: actions/checkout@v3      - name: ‚éî Setup node        uses: actions/setup-node@v3        with:          node-version: 20      - name: üì• Download deps        uses: bahmutov/npm-install@v1      - name: üåê Install Playwright Browsers        run: npx playwright install --with-deps      - name: üõ† Setup Database        run: npm run prisma:wipe        env:          DATABASE_URL: postgresql://postgres:postgres@localhost:5432/testdb      - name: üé≠ Playwright Run        run: npx playwright test        env:          DATABASE_URL: postgresql://postgres:postgres@localhost:5432/testdb      - name: üì∏ Playwright Screenshots        uses: actions/upload-artifact@v4        if: failure()        with:          name: playwright-report

document: How to Set Up Next.js 15 for Production in 2025

ReactSquadby EarlyNodeHomeBlogResourcesResource Link 1Resource Link 2Resource Link 3Start hiringBlogHow to Set Up Next.js 15 for Production in 2025Next.jsTutorialsHow to Set Up Next.js 15 for Production in 2025Jan HestersChief Technical Officer, ReactSquadMarch 15, 2025I've worked on Next.js applications that scaled to over 100k monthly active users and landing pages with millions of monthly visitors. In this article, I'll share all the lessons I've learned through countless iterations.Whether you're part of a small team of one, two, or three developers, or you work on a massive Next.js project with multiple teams on the same codebase, it's critical to get the foundation of your app right from the start. Even if you're working on an existing project, you will discover some hard-earned insights that you can apply to your app today.Let me take you by the hand and show you all the steps and packages that you want to set up and explain to you why they're useful, so your app scales
and packages that you want to set up and explain to you why they're useful, so your app scales smoothly.Initialize Your ProjectBegin by creating a new Next.js project.npx create-next-app@latest

It may ask you if it can install the latest create-next-app version, just hit yes.Need to install the following packages:
create-next-app@15.0.0
Ok to proceed? (y)
And then configure your project by hitting yes on everything (TypeScript, Tailwind, app router).‚úî **What is your project named?** ‚Ä¶ reactsquad-production
‚úî **Would you like to use** **TypeScript****?** ‚Ä¶ No / Yes
Yes
‚úî **Would you like to use** **ESLint****?** ‚Ä¶ No / Yes
Yes
‚úî **Would you like to use** **Tailwind CSS****?** ‚Ä¶ No / Yes
Yes
‚úî **Would you like to use** **`src/` directory****?** ‚Ä¶ No / Yes
Yes
‚úî **Would you like to use** **App Router****? (recommended)** ‚Ä¶ No / Yes
Yes
‚úî **Would you like to customize the default** **import alias** **(@/*)?** ‚Ä¶ No / No
Then change into the directory of your project and open it in your favorite editor.$ cd nextjs-for-production
~/dev/nextjs-for-production (main) ü§Ø
$ cursor .

~/dev/nextjs-for-production (main) ü§Ø
$ cursor .
Run The Development ServerYou want to verify that your setup worked.Run npm run dev to start the development server.Visit http://localhost:3000 to view your application.Type Checks With TypeScriptYour project has TypeScript already configured, but you also want to add an explicit command to your package.json that checks all your files for type errors."type-check": "tsc -b"

You're going to use this command later together with other automated static analysis checks.Code FormattingWhen you collaborate with a large team on a project, it's important to unify the way that everyone writes code. Discuss choices like using semicolons, quote styles, and tabs versus spaces with your team.Then use tools to enforce your style guide and format code automatically.There are two tools for that: Prettier and ESLint.PrettierPrettier is an opinionated code formatter that eliminates style discussions during code reviews.Install Prettier together with its Tailwind plugin.npm install --save-dev prettier prettier-plugin-tailwindcss
Create a prettier.config.js file with your preferred rules.module.exports = {
  arrowParens: 'avoid',
  bracketSameLine: false,
  bracketSpacing: true,
  htmlWhitespaceSensitivity: 'css',
  insertPragma: false,
  jsxSingleQuote: false,
  plugins: ['prettier-plugin-tailwindcss'],
  printWidth: 80,
  proseWrap: 'always',
  quoteProps: 'as-needed',

printWidth: 80,
  proseWrap: 'always',
  quoteProps: 'as-needed',
  requirePragma: false,
  semi: true,
  singleQuote: true,
  tabWidth: 2,
  trailingComma: 'all',
  useTabs: false,
};
Add a formatting script to your package.json."format": "prettier --write .",
Run the formatter to apply your style.$ npm run format

> nextjs-for-production@0.1.0 format
> prettier --write .

next.config.mjs 4ms (unchanged)
package-lock.json 54ms (unchanged)
package.json 1ms (unchanged)
postcss.config.mjs 2ms (unchanged)
README.md 20ms (unchanged)
src/app/globals.css 17ms (unchanged)
src/app/layout.tsx 30ms (unchanged)
src/app/page.tsx 11ms (unchanged)
tailwind.config.ts 2ms (unchanged)
tsconfig.json 2ms (unchanged)
Your files are now "prettier", but you also want to use ESLint.ESLintESLint can scan your code for both stylistic and logical issues. Install ESLint and its plugins, like unicorn, playwright and import sort.npm install --save-dev @typescript-eslint/parser eslint-plugin-unicorn eslint-plugin-import eslint-plugin-playwright eslint-config-prettier eslint-plugin-prettier eslint-plugin-simple-import-sort
Update your .eslintrc.json.{
  "extends": [
    "next/core-web-vitals",
    "plugin:unicorn/recommended",
    "plugin:import/recommended",
    "plugin:playwright/recommended",
    "plugin:prettier/recommended"
  ],
  "plugins": ["simple-import-sort"],
  "rules": {

> nextjs-for-production@0.1.0 lint:fix
> next lint --fix

‚úî No ESLint warnings or errors
If you get a TypeScript version warning, you can ignore that.Note: As of this article's writing, ESLint 9 is available, but this tutorial uses ESLint 8 because many plugins do not yet support the latest version.CommitlintWhen collaborating with a large team, it's also helpful to enforce consistent commit messages to keep the project history clear. By choosing the right standards, you can automate changelog and release generation with correct semantic versioning.Install Commitlint and its necessary configurations. This includes Husky, which helps manage Git hooks.npm install --save-dev @commitlint/cli@latest @commitlint/config-conventional@latest husky@latest

Add hooks to automate linting and type checking before each commit, and customize your commit message workflow.npx husky add .husky/pre-commit 'npm run lint && npm run type-check'

npx husky add .husky/prepare-commit-msg 'exec < /dev/tty && npx cz --hook || true'
The pre-commit hook runs after git commit, but before the commit message is finalized and runs linting and type-checking on your code.The prepare-commit-msg hook runs after git commit is initiated but before the commit message editor opens. It runs commitizen CLI to let you craft conventional commit messages. You'll learn how to use this hook in a bit.Remove the line that says npm test from .husky/_/pre-commit.Make sure these scripts are executable.chmod a+x .husky/pre-commit
chmod a+x .husky/prepare-commit-msg
Here, chmod stands for "change mode." This command allows you to change the access permissions or modes of a file or directory in Unix and Unix-like operating systems. The argument a+x adds execute permissions for all users.Install Commitizen, which provides a CLI for crafting conventional commit messages.npm install --save-dev commitizen cz-conventional-changelog

System requirements

Before you begin, make sure your system meets the following requirements:

Node.js 18.18 or later.
macOS, Windows (including WSL), or Linux.

Automatic installation

Node.js 18.18 or later.
macOS, Windows (including WSL), or Linux.

Automatic installation





The quickest way to create a new Next.js app is using create-next-app, which sets up everything automatically for you. To create a project, run:
Terminalnpx create-next-app@latest
On installation, you'll see the following prompts:
TerminalWhat is your project named? my-app
Would you like to use TypeScript? No / Yes
Would you like to use ESLint? No / Yes
Would you like to use Tailwind CSS? No / Yes
Would you like your code inside a `src/` directory? No / Yes
Would you like to use App Router? (recommended) No / Yes
Would you like to use Turbopack for `next dev`?  No / Yes
Would you like to customize the import alias (`@/*` by default)? No / Yes
What import alias would you like configured? @/*
After the prompts, create-next-app will create a folder with your project name and install the required dependencies.
Manual installation

To manually create a new Next.js app, install the required packages:
Terminalnpm install next@latest react@latest react-dom@latest
Then, add the following scripts to your package.json file:
package.json{
  "scripts": {
    "dev": "next dev",
    "build": "next build",
    "start": "next start",
    "lint": "next lint"
  }
}
These scripts refer to the different stages of developing an application:

next dev: Starts the development server.
next build: Builds the application for production.
next start: Starts the production server.
next lint: Runs ESLint.

Create the app directory

If you forget to create the root layout, Next.js will automatically create this file when running the development server with next dev.
You can optionally use a src folder in the root of your project to separate your application's code from configuration files.



Create the public folder (optional)





Create a public folder at the root of your project to store static assets such as images, fonts, etc. Files inside public can then be referenced by your code starting from the base URL (/).
You can then reference these assets using the root path (/). For example, public/profile.png can be referenced as /profile.png:
app/page.tsxTypeScriptJavaScriptTypeScriptimport Image from 'next/image'
 
export default function Page() {
  return <Image src="/profile.png" alt="Profile" width={100} height={100} />
}

Run the development server

Run the development server






Run npm run dev to start the development server.
Visit http://localhost:3000 to view your application.
Edit theapp/page.tsx  file and save it to see the updated result in your browser.

Set up TypeScript






Minimum TypeScript version: v4.5.2

Next.js comes with built-in TypeScript support. To add TypeScript to your project, rename a file to .ts / .tsx and run next dev. Next.js will automatically install the necessary dependencies and add a tsconfig.json file with the recommended config options.
IDE Plugin




Next.js includes a custom TypeScript plugin and type checker, which VSCode and other code editors can use for advanced type-checking and auto-completion.You can enable the plugin in VS Code by:
Opening the command palette (Ctrl/‚åò + Shift + P)
Searching for "TypeScript: Select TypeScript Version"
Selecting "Use Workspace Version"

See the TypeScript reference page for more information.
Set up ESLint

See the TypeScript reference page for more information.
Set up ESLint





Next.js comes with built-in ESLint. It automatically installs the necessary packages and configures the proper settings when you create a new project with create-next-app.
To manually add ESLint to an existing project, add next lint as a script to package.json:
package.json{
  "scripts": {
    "lint": "next lint"
  }
}
Then, run npm run lint and you will be guided through the installation and configuration process.
Terminalnpm run lint
You'll see a prompt like this:

? How would you like to configure ESLint?
‚ùØ Strict (recommended)
Base
Cancel


Strict: Includes Next.js' base ESLint configuration along with a stricter Core Web Vitals rule-set. This is the recommended configuration for developers setting up ESLint for the first time.
Base: Includes Next.js' base ESLint configuration.
Cancel: Skip configuration. Select this option if you plan on setting up your own custom ESLint configuration.

If Strict or Base are selected, Next.js will automatically install eslint and eslint-config-next as dependencies in your application and create an .eslintrc.json file in the root of your project that includes your selected configuration.
You can now run next lint every time you want to run ESLint to catch errors. Once ESLint has been set up, it will also automatically run during every build (next build). Errors will fail the build, while warnings will not.
See the ESLint Plugin page for more information.

              Creating a project with NextJS, Typescript and ChakraUI in 3 steps.
            

#chakra
#typescript
#nextjs
#yarn

In modern times speed, efficiency and functionality are one of the many elements that makes a web application ‚Äúsuper‚Äù.  One way we can achieve this gem is by using quality web-building tools like NextJS- to enhance web performance such as lazy-image loading, Typescript- to keep code quality and avoid future spills and ChakraUI- to build accessibly user-friend interfaces. 
This article will be working us through how we can combine these ‚Äúpowers‚Äù to build a ‚Äúsuperpowered‚Äù web application
Step One- Initiate NextJS with Typescript: (Docs)
In our terminal, navigate to a directory to create a new project. Using your preferred package manager, let‚Äôs create a React project powered with NextJS and Typescript using this command: 
yarn create next-app --typescript or npx create-next-app@latest --ts. 
In the process of running this command, the terminal will pop up a dialog asking us to name our new project. Let‚Äôs call it doggies (A Dog-interest website) and we are golden!
PS: The --ts or --typescript is a flag to tell the package manager to initiate a React project with Typescript.

Step Two- Install ChakraUI: (Docs)
After successfully creating our project that is powered with NextJS and Typescript, let‚Äôs now install ChakraUI. Before running the command to install ChakraUI, navigate to the root of the project, then go ahead to install ChakraUI using this command: 
yarn add @chakra-ui/react @emotion/react@^11 @emotion/styled@^11 framer-motion@^6
or
npm i @chakra-ui/react @emotion/react@^11 @emotion/styled@^11 framer-motion@^6 
And that‚Äôs it! ChakraUI is now available on our project. To have full access to the goodies that comes with ChakraUI we need to do one last thing and that takes us to step number 3.


Step Three- Activate the power of ChakraUI.
To do this, we need to access the _app.tsx file inside our Pages folder of our project and wrap its return components in a ChakraProvider Component. 
This is what the file looks like by default:


import type { AppProps } from 'next/app'

export default MyApp;



Enter fullscreen mode


Exit fullscreen mode






And there it is! Our application is now powered with NextJS, Typescript and ChakraUI. 
To see the smooth user interfaces your can create with ChakraUI you can check the documentation of all its components here. 
I‚Äôll be writing an article about why this setup is my favourite and what opportunities this gives us, until then, have a good day and stay well!

              Creating a Next.js project with Chakra-UI integration
            

#nextjs
#tutorial
#beginners
#javascript








  Introduction

Hello, in this tutorial I will show you how to create a simple Next.js project with Chakra UI intergration. üëÄ




  What is Chakra-UI

Chakra-UI is an open source component library used for building modular, accessible and good looking user interfaces. 
The main advantages of Chakra-UI are as follows:

Accessibility: Chakra-UI allows us to use pre-build components created by the Chakra-UI team.
Themeable: The library ships with a default theme, which can be customized if needed.
Light and dark mode: both are supported out of the box and can rely on the user's system settings. For example if the user sets their computer to dark mode by default, Chakra-UI will default to dark mode.
Composibility: Components can be created from the Chakra-UI ones or if needed custom components can be created with ease.
Typescript Support: Chakra-UI is written in TypeScript and provides class types for easy integration.





  What we will be making

In this tutorial we will use Chakra-UI to create a simple user list/profile page. 
We will also integrate a toggler to toggle between light and dark mode.
You will learn how to set up a basic Next.js application with Chakra-UI integration.




  Creating the Next.js application and installing the dependencies

Creating the Next.js application and installing the dependencies

First we need to create a new Next.js app and install the dependencies needed for the example.
The Next.js app can be created via the following command:



npx create-next-app@latest





Enter fullscreen mode


Exit fullscreen mode





This will set up the Next.js project automatically for you.
Next we need to install Chakra-ui which can be done via the following command:



yarn add @chakra-ui/react @emotion/react@^11 @emotion/styled@^11 framer-motion@^4 @chakra-ui/icons





Enter fullscreen mode


Exit fullscreen mode









  Creating fake Users

Next we will need some fake users to actually populate the page. 
Create a "data" folder in the root directory and create a "users.js" file and populate it with the following data: (feel free to use your own custom data but be careful of the parameter names):
https://github.com/ethand91/nextjs-chakra-sample/blob/main/data/users.js




  Creating the components

Enter fullscreen mode


Exit fullscreen mode





Here we basically list all the users using Chakra-UI's Grid component. The "gridTemplateColumns" allows us to set the sizes for small screens, medium screens and large screens. For example if you view the page on a large screen each row will have 3 users, however if you view it on a mobile device each row will only have one user.
Feel free to run the project using:



npm run dev





Enter fullscreen mode


Exit fullscreen mode





If you access the page (https://localhost:3000), you should see the following page:

If you prefer light mode you should see the following:

<Avatar size="lg" src={ user.avatar } />
            <Box marginLeft="6">
              <Text as="h1" fontSize="xx-large" fontWeight="bold">
                { user.first_name } { user.last_name }
              </Text>
              <Text as="p" fontSize="large" lineHeight="1.5">
                { user.job_title }
              </Text>
            </Box>
          </Flex>
        </Box>
        <Box
          maxW="container.xl"
          margin="auto"
          padding="8"
          backgroundColor={
            useColorModeValue('white', 'gray.700')
          }
        >
          <Text as="p">{ user.description }</Text>
          <Link href="/" passHref>
            <Button marginTop="8" colorScheme="whatsapp" as="a">
              Back to all users
            </Button>
          </Link>
        </Box>
      </Box>
    </Center>
  );
};

export default UserPage;





Enter fullscreen mode


Exit fullscreen mode

export default UserPage;





Enter fullscreen mode


Exit fullscreen mode





Phew! Here we use "getStaticPaths" to tell Next.js we need to render a new page for each user in the user's array.
We also tell Next.js to display the default 404 page if the requested user is not found.
Chakra-UI allows us to easily center the contents. This page basically displays the contents of the user and provides a button to go back using a Chakra-UI feature.
All done fire up the dev server and load up https://localhost:3000 in the browser. 
Once loading try clicking on a user you should see the following page:


All done! üòé




  Conclusion

Here I have demonstrated how to use Next.js with Chakra-UI. Feel free to customize anyway you wish. üòâ
I'm actually thinking of using Next.js for my next side project.
Hopefully you have learned something new, you can find the source code for this tutorial via:
https://github.com/ethand91/nextjs-chakra-sample

This example features how to use chakra-ui as the component library within a Next.js app with typescript.
Next.js and chakra-ui have built-in TypeScript declarations, so we'll get autocompletion for their modules straight away.
We are connecting the Next.js _app.js with chakra-ui's Provider and theme so the pages can have app-wide dark/light mode. We are also creating some components which shows the usage of chakra-ui's style props.
Deploy your own
Deploy the example using Vercel:

How to use
Using create-next-app
Execute create-next-app with npm or Yarn to bootstrap the example:
npx create-next-app --example with-chakra-ui-typescript with-chakra-ui-typescript-app
# or
yarn create next-app --example with-chakra-ui-typescript with-chakra-ui-typescript-app
Deploy it to the cloud with Vercel (Documentation).
Notes
Chakra has supported Gradients and RTL in v1.1. To utilize RTL, add RTL direction and swap.
If you don't have multi-direction app, you should make <Html lang="ar" dir="rtl"> inside _document.ts.

The Qwen3 series is a family of large language models developed by Alibaba Cloud's Qwen team. It includes various model sizes ranging from 0.6 billion to 235 billion parameters, with some of the publicly available models being Qwen3-0.6B, Qwen3-1.7B, Qwen3-4B, Qwen3-8B, Qwen3-14B, and Qwen3-32B [1]. These models support 119 languages and were trained on a vast dataset of nearly 36 trillion tokens, which includes textbooks, question-answer pairs, code snippets, and AI-generated data [1].

The Qwen3 models have been optimized for reasoning and quick response capabilities. They were further enhanced through reinforcement learning across over 20 general-domain tasks, improving their ability to follow instructions, adhere to formats, and demonstrate agent-like behaviors [1]. Notably, the largest public Qwen3 model, Qwen3-32B, is competitive with other proprietary and open AI models, such as DeepSeek‚Äôs R1 and surpasses OpenAI's o1 model in several benchmarks [1].

For deployment, users can leverage frameworks like SGLang and vLLM for deployment, while tools such as Ollama, LMStudio, MLX, llama.cpp, and KTransformers are recommended for local usage [1]. The models are available under the Apache 2.0 license and can be accessed via platforms like Hugging Face, ModelScope, and Kaggle [1].

The largest public Qwen3 model, Qwen3-32B, is still competitive with a number of proprietary and open AI models, including Chinese AI lab DeepSeek‚Äôs R1. Qwen3-32B surpasses OpenAI‚Äôs o1 model on several tests, including the coding benchmark LiveCodeBench.
Alibaba says Qwen3 ‚Äúexcels‚Äù in tool-calling capabilities as well as¬†following instructions and copying specific data formats. In addition to the models for download, Qwen3 is available from cloud providers, including Fireworks AI and Hyperbolic.
Tuhin Srivastava, co-founder and CEO of AI cloud host Baseten, said that Qwen3 is another point in the trend line of open models keeping pace with closed source systems such as OpenAI‚Äôs.

Kyle Wiggers





2:37 PM PDT ¬∑ April 28, 2025 







 


 

 

 

 

 

 






Chinese tech company Alibaba on Monday released Qwen3, a family of AI models the company claims matches and in some cases outperforms the best models available from Google and OpenAI.
Most of the models are ‚Äî or soon will be ‚Äî available for download under an ‚Äúopen‚Äù license from AI dev platform Hugging Face and GitHub. They range in size from 0.6 billion parameters to 235 billion parameters. Parameters roughly correspond to a model‚Äôs problem-solving skills, and models with more parameters generally perform better than those with fewer parameters.








The rise of China-originated model series like Qwen have increased the pressure on American labs such as OpenAI to deliver more capable AI technologies. They‚Äôve also led policymakers to implement restrictions aimed at limiting the ability of Chinese AI companies to obtain the chips necessary to train models.

The Qwen3 models support 119 languages, Alibaba says, and were trained on a dataset of nearly 36 trillion tokens. Tokens are the raw bits of data that a model processes; 1 million tokens is equivalent to about 750,000 words. Alibaba says that Qwen3 was trained on a combination of textbooks, ‚Äúquestion-answer pairs,‚Äù code snippets, AI-generated data, and more.
These improvements, along with others, greatly boosted Qwen3‚Äôs capabilities compared to its predecessor, Qwen2, says Alibaba. None of the Qwen3 models are head and shoulders above top-of-the-line recent models like OpenAI‚Äôs o3 and o4-mini, but they‚Äôre strong performers nonetheless.
On Codeforces, a platform for programming contests, the largest Qwen3 model ‚Äî Qwen-3-235B-A22B ‚Äî just beats out OpenAI‚Äôs o3-mini and Google‚Äôs Gemini 2.5 Pro. Qwen-3-235B-A22B also bests o3-mini on the latest version of AIME, a challenging math benchmark, and BFCL, a test for assessing a model‚Äôs ability to ‚Äúreason‚Äù about problems.

These improvements, along with others, greatly boosted Qwen3‚Äôs capabilities compared to its predecessor, Qwen2, says Alibaba. None of the Qwen3 models are head and shoulders above top-of-the-line recent models like OpenAI‚Äôs o3 and o4-mini, but they‚Äôre strong performers nonetheless.
On Codeforces, a platform for programming contests, the largest Qwen3 model ‚Äî Qwen-3-235B-A22B ‚Äî just beats out OpenAI‚Äôs o3-mini and Google‚Äôs Gemini 2.5 Pro. Qwen-3-235B-A22B also bests o3-mini on the latest version of AIME, a challenging math benchmark, and BFCL, a test for assessing a model‚Äôs ability to ‚Äúreason‚Äù about problems.

Here's a Python script to access MCP servers using **Qwen3** as the LLM backend. This example uses `pydantic-ai` and integrates with MCP servers like `mcp-server-time` and `mcp-server-fetch`, as shown in the context [1]:

```python
import os
from pydantic_ai import Agent
from pydantic_ai.models.openai import OpenAIModel
from pydantic_ai.providers.openai import OpenAIProvider
from pydantic_ai.mcp import MCPServerStdio

# --- 1. Configure the LLM backend (Qwen3) ---
llm = OpenAIModel(
    model_name="qwen3:30b",  # Use the correct model tag
    provider=OpenAIProvider(
        base_url="http://localhost:11434/v1",  # Ollama or proxy URL
    ),
)

# --- 2. Define MCP servers to use ---
mcp_servers = [
    MCPServerStdio(
        command="uvx",  # Use the correct executable (e.g., `npx` or `uvx`)
        args=["mcp-server-time", "--local-timezone=Asia/Shanghai"]
    ),
    MCPServerStdio(
        command="uvx",
        args=["mcp-server-fetch"]
    ),
]

# --- 3. Create the Agent ---
agent = Agent(
    model=llm,
    mcp_servers=mcp_servers,
    system_message="You are a helpful assistant. Use MCP tools for accurate answers."
)

# --- 4. Define a function to run queries ---
def ask(query: str):
    async def run():
        async with agent.run_mcp_servers():
            result = await agent.run(query)
            print(result.output)

    anyio.run(run)

# Example usage
ask("What time is it in Shanghai and what's the weather there?")
```

---

### Key Notes:
1. **LLM Backend**: The script assumes Qwen3 is served via Ollama (`http://localhost:11424/v1`) or a proxy. Adjust the `base_url` and `model_name` as needed.
2. **MCP Servers**: The example uses `mcp-server-time` and `mcp-server-fetch`. Replace these with other servers (e.g., `@modelcontextprotocol/server-brave-search`) as needed [1].
3. **Dependencies**: Install required packages:
   ```bash
   pip install pydantic-ai-slim[mcp,streaming] mcp anyio
   ```
4. **Runtime**: Ensure `uvx` or `npx` is available in your environment to launch MCP servers [1].

You can install this server in Claude Desktop and interact with it right away by running:
mcp install server.py
Alternatively, you can test it with the MCP Inspector:
mcp dev server.py
What is MCP?
The Model Context Protocol (MCP) lets you build servers that expose data and functionality to LLM applications in a secure, standardized way. Think of it like a web API, but specifically designed for LLM interactions. MCP servers can:

Expose data through Resources (think of these sort of like GET endpoints; they are used to load information into the LLM's context)
Provide functionality through Tools (sort of like POST endpoints; they are used to execute code or otherwise produce a side effect)
Define interaction patterns through Prompts (reusable templates for LLM interactions)
And more!

Finetuning
We advise you to use training frameworks, including Axolotl, unsloth, Swift, Llama-Factory, etc., to finetune your models with SFT, DPO, GRPO, etc.
License Agreement

Citation

LMStudio
Qwen3 has already been supported by lmstudio.ai. You can directly use LMStudio with our GGUF files.
MLX-LM
If you are running on Apple Silicon, mlx-lm also supports Qwen3 (mlx-lm>=0.24.0).
Look for models ending with MLX on HuggingFace Hub.
Deploy Qwen3
Qwen3 is supported by multiple inference frameworks.
Here we demonstrate the usage of SGLang and vLLM.
You can also find Qwen3 models from various inference providers, e.g., Alibaba Cloud Model Studio.
SGLang
SGLang is a fast serving framework for large language models and vision language models.
SGLang could be used to launch a server with OpenAI-compatible API service.
sglang>=0.4.6.post1 is required.
It is as easy as
python -m sglang.launch_server --model-path Qwen/Qwen3-8B --port 30000 --reasoning-parser qwen3
An OpenAI-compatible API will be available at http://localhost:30000/v1.
vLLM
vLLM is a high-throughput and memory-efficient inference and serving engine for LLMs.
vllm>=0.8.4 is required.

The post-trained models do not use the "-Instruct" suffix any more. For example, Qwen3-32B is the newer version of Qwen2.5-32B-Instruct.
The base models now have names ending with "-Base".

Here's a Python script to access MCP servers using **Qwen3** as the LLM backend. This example uses `pydantic-ai` and integrates with MCP servers like `mcp-server-time` and `mcp-server-fetch`, as shown in the context [1]:
```python
import os
from pydantic_ai import Agent
from pydantic_ai.models.openai import OpenAIModel
from pydantic_ai.providers.openai import OpenAIProvider
from pydantic_ai.mcp import MCPServerStdio
# --- 1. Configure the LLM backend (Qwen3) ---
llm = OpenAIModel(
    model_name="qwen3:30b",  # Use the correct model tag
    provider=OpenAIProvider(
        base_url="http://localhost:11434/v1",  # Ollama or proxy URL
    ),
)
# --- 2. Define MCP servers to use ---
mcp_servers = [
    MCPServerStdio(
        command="uvx",  # Use the correct executable (e.g., `npx` or `uvx`)
        args=["mcp-server-time", "--local-timezone=Asia/Shanghai"]
    ),
    MCPServerStdio(
        command="uvx",
        args=["mcp-server-fetch"]
    ),
]
# --- 3. Create the Agent ---
agent = Agent(
    model=llm,
    mcp_servers=mcp_servers,
    system_message="You are a helpful assistant. Use MCP tools for accurate answers."
)
# --- 4. Define a function to run queries ---
def ask(query: str):
    async def run():
        async with agent.run_mcp_servers():
            result = await agent.run(query)
            print(result.output)
    anyio.run(run)
# Example usage
ask("What time is it in Shanghai and what's the weather there?")
```
---
### Key Notes:
1. **LLM Backend**: The script assumes Qwen3 is served via Ollama (`http://localhost:11424/v1`) or a proxy. Adjust the `base_url` and `model_name` as needed.
2. **MCP Servers**: The example uses `mcp-server-time` and `mcp-server-fetch`. Replace these with other servers (e.g., `@modelcontextprotocol/server-brave-search`) as needed [1].
3. **Dependencies**: Install required packages:
   ```bash
   pip install pydantic-ai-slim[mcp,streaming] mcp anyio
   ```
4. **Runtime**: Ensure `uvx` or `npx` is available in your environment to launch MCP servers [1].
For advanced use, you can extend this with tools like `code_interpreter` or integrate with Claude Desktop [1]. Let me know if you need help deploying specific servers!

### **2. MCP Server Integration with Qwen3**  
- **MCP (Model Context Protocol)**: A framework for LLMs to interact with external tools/servers.  
- **Use Case**: Querying real-time data (e.g., time zones, weather) via servers like `mcp-server-time` and `mcp-server-fetch`.  
- **Tools Required**:

    # Run the async function

<source id=" 1 ">The Open WebUI is a self-hosted, open-source web interface for LLMs. It provides an intuitive and user-friendly experience to manage models, chat with them, and customize their behavior. The interface supports multiple backends such as Ollama, LMStudio, and other OpenAI-compatible APIs. It allows users to create custom models using a Modelfile, which defines the model‚Äôs behavior and system prompts. The interface also includes features like document management for Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG), user authentication, and API key management. Open WebUI is designed to be flexible, allowing users to deploy it with Docker or directly via Python. It's particularly useful for those who want a centralized platform to manage and interact with various LLMs without needing complex configurations [1].</source>


To install and run Open WebUI on Windows localhost, follow these steps:

1. **Install Ollama**: Download and install Ollama from [ollama.com](https://ollama.com). Once installed, you can pull models using the command `ollama pull modelname` [1].

2. **Install Open WebUI**:
   - Using Docker: Run the following command in your terminal:
     ```
     docker run -d -p 3000:8080 --add-host=host.docker.internal:host-gateway -v open-webui:/app/backend/data --name open-webui --restart always ghcr.io/open-webui/open-webui:main
     ```
   - Alternatively, you can install Open WebUI using Python:
     ```
     pip install open-webui
     open-webui serve
     ```

3. **Access Open WebUI**: Open your browser and navigate to `http://localhost:3000` [1].

4. **Configure LLM Providers**: After logging in, go to Settings ‚Üí Connections and add your API keys for the services you want to use. Open WebUI supports any OpenAI-compatible endpoints [1].

5. **Manage Models**: You can manage models through the admin console by navigating to Settings ‚Üí Models and toggling the activation switch next to each model name [1].

For more detailed information, refer to the official Open WebUI documentation.

Additional Note to OpenWebUI‚Äôs web search settings
If your LLM has a long context window (like Gemini), you can bypass embedding and retrieval in the Web Search settings. This prevents search results from being indexed in the vector database and instead feeds them directly into the LLM‚Äôs context window, potentially improving chat speed.



Some users might prefer this approach for better search results, but personally, I don‚Äôt like it. The reason is that if I enable it, I lose the flexibility to switch to models with smaller context windows easily.

A step by step guide for installing and running Ollama and OpenwebUi locally: part 1

Step 1: download and installation 
Installing openweb UI is very easy. There are several ways on the official Openweb UI website to install and run it:Install with dockerInstalling with PodmanInstalling without docker! Installing Ollama and how it works
First, you need to install Ollama If you don‚Äôt have installed Ollama on your computer you can install it by visiting this link: ollama.com and clicking on download.

Running Openweb UI:
After installing Ollama all you need to do to set up the interface is runnig this docker command:
docker run -d -p 3000:8080 --add-host=host.docker.internal:host-gateway -v open-webui:/app/backend/data --name open-webui --restart always ghcr.io/open-webui/open-webui:main
Here we go, now you can access Open WebUI at¬†http://localhost:3000.
Installing by cloning open web UI repository
You can also install and run openweb UI by Cloning the official open web UI repository on GitHub. you can find it in this link:https://github.com/open-webui/open-webui/Open your terminal or command prompt and navigate to the directory where your Docker Compose files are located. Run the following command to start the Ollama application:
docker compose up -d --build

To use **tools** and **function calling features** in Open WebUI with the Qwen3 model, follow these steps. This includes executing Python code and applying diff patches to files (with caveats about sandboxing).

---

### **1. Enable Code Execution in Open WebUI**
Open WebUI supports code execution via a sandboxed environment (gVisor) for security. To use it with Qwen3:

#### **Step 1: Install the Code Execution Tool**
- Go to **Workspace ‚Üí Tools** in Open WebUI.
- Click **+ Add Tool** and input:
  - **Toolkit Name**: `Run code`
  - **Description**: "Run arbitrary code safely in a gVisor sandbox."
  - Replace the code section with `open-webui/tools/run_code.py` (ensure this file exists).
  - Click **Save**.

#### **Step 2: Enable the Tool for Qwen3**
- Go to **Workspace ‚Üí Models**.
- Find your Qwen3 model and click the pencil (‚úèÔ∏è) icon.
- Under **Tools**, check the box for `Run code`.
- Click **Save & Update**.

---

### **2. Example: Execute Python Code with Qwen3**
Once enabled, you can prompt Qwen3 to execute code:

#### **Prompt Example**:
> "Run a Python script that calculates the sum of numbers from 1 to 10."

#### **How It Works**:
- Qwen3 generates the code (e.g., `sum(range(1, 11))`).
- You click the **Run code** button in Open WebUI (if enabled as a tool).
- The output appears in the UI.

#### **Code Execution via Tool**:
You can also define a custom tool (e.g., `check_system_status`) as shown in the context [1], which is triggered by a system prompt:
```python
class Tools:
    def check_system_status():
        print("‚úÖ System status: Active")
        return "System status: Active"
```
- This function is registered in Open WebUI and can be invoked by Qwen3 via the tool system.

---

### **3. Example: Apply a Diff Patch to a File**
Applying diff patches requires direct file system access, which is **sandboxed** in Open WebUI. However, you can use the `Run code` tool to simulate this:

#### **Step 1: Generate a Diff Patch**
Prompt Qwen3 to generate a diff (e.g., for a file `example.txt`):
```python
# Example: Create a diff patch (hypothetical scenario)
import difflib

original = "Hello, world!\n"
modified = "Hello, Open WebUI!\n"

diff = difflib.unified_diff(original.splitlines(), modified.splitlines())
print("\n".join(diff))
```

#### **Step 2: Apply the Diff (Limited Scope)**
- Open WebUI‚Äôs code execution is sandboxed, so **direct file system access** (e.g., `patch` or `git apply`) is restricted.
- If your use case allows, you can:
  - Use the `Run code` tool to generate diffs.
  - Manually apply patches in a local environment outside the sandbox.

#### **Workaround for Sandboxed Environments**:
If you must apply patches within Open WebUI, use the `run_code.py` tool to write files to a sandboxed directory (e.g., `/tmp/`). Example:
```python
with open("/tmp/example.txt", "w") as f:
    f.write("Hello, Open WebUI!\n")
```

---

### **4. Key Limitations**
- **Sandboxing**: Open WebUI‚Äôs code execution is restricted to a gVisor sandbox. Direct file system access (e.g., modifying files outside `/tmp/`) is not allowed.
- **Tool Compatibility**: Ensure the Qwen3 model supports function calling via Open WebUI‚Äôs tool system. If not, use system prompts to trigger code execution.

---

### **5. Summary**
- Use Open WebUI‚Äôs `Run code` tool to execute Python scripts with Qwen3.
- For diff patches, generate diffs via code execution and apply them manually or within the sandboxed environment.
- Ensure tools are enabled for your Qwen3 model and verify compatibility with Open WebUI‚Äôs sandboxed execution.

For further details, refer to the [Open WebUI documentation](https://github.com/open-webui/open-webui) or check the context [1] for tool configuration steps.

Overview‚Äã
Open WebUI allows for the client-side execution of Python code in the browser, utilizing Pyodide to run scripts within a code block in a chat. This feature enables Large Language Models (LLMs) to generate Python scripts that can be executed directly in the browser, leveraging a range of libraries supported by Pyodide.

To maintain user privacy and flexibility, Open WebUI mirrors PyPI packages, avoiding direct external network requests. This approach also enables the use of Pyodide in environments without internet access.
The Open WebUI frontend includes a self-contained WASM (WebAssembly) Python environment, powered by Pyodide, which can execute basic Python scripts generated by LLMs. This environment is designed for ease of use, requiring no additional setup or installation.

subprocess.run(["uv", "init", project_name], check=True)

# Step 3: Create virtual environment
subprocess.run(["uv", "venv"], check=True)
subprocess.run(["source", ".venv/bin/activate"], shell=True, check=True)

# Step 4: Install required dependencies
subprocess.run(["uv", "add", "mcp[cli]", "pandas", "pyarrow"], check=True)

# Step 5: Create server.py
with open("server.py", "w") as f:
    f.write('''from mcp.server.fastmcp import FastMCP

# This is the shared MCP server instance
mcp = FastMCP("time_server")
''')

# Step 6: Create main.py to run the server
with open("main.py", "w") as f:
    f.write('''from server import mcp

if __name__ == "__main__":
    mcp.run()
''')

# Step 7: Configure MCP server to use mcp-server-time
with open("mcp_settings.json", "w") as f:
    f.write('''{
  "mcpServers": {
    "time": {
      "command": "uvx",
      "args": ["mcp-server-time"]
    }
  }
}
''')

# Step 8: Run the server
print("Project setup complete. Running the MCP server...")
subprocess.run(["uv", "run", "main.py"], check=True)
```

### **Explanation of the Script**

1. **Project Initialization**: 
   - Creates a directory named `time_mcp_server` and changes into it.
   - Uses `uv init` to set up a new Python project with the specified name.

2. **Virtual Environment**:
   - Creates a virtual environment using `uv venv`.
   - Activates the virtual environment (note: activation in a script may require `shell=True` for Windows, but this example assumes Unix-like systems).

3. **Dependencies Installation**:
   - Installs `mcp[cli]`, `pandas`, and `pyarrow` using `uv add`.

4. **Server Configuration**:
   - Creates a `server.py` file with the FastMCP instance.
   - Creates a `main.py` file to run the server.
   - Sets up an `mcp_settings.json` file to configure the MCP server with `mcp-server-time`.

5. **Execution**:
   - Runs the server using `uv run main.py`.

### **Next Steps**
- Ensure `uv` and `uvx` are installed on your system.
- The script assumes a Unix-like environment (Linux/macOS). For Windows, adjust the activation command.
- The `mcp-server-time` tool must be installed. If not, install it using:
  ```bash
  uvx install mcp-server-time
  ```
- The server will now be accessible via the configured MCP settings, allowing interaction with time-related tools.

```

This repository contains the model code, documentation, and related resources. The Qwen3 series includes various models with different sizes and capabilities, such as Qwen3-7B, Qwen3-14B, and Qwen3-72B.

This was my original request:

```

</source>


The Qwen3 series is a family of large language models developed by Alibaba Cloud's Qwen team. It includes various model sizes ranging from 0.6 billion to 235 billion parameters, with some of the publicly available models being Qwen3-0.6B, Qwen3-1.7B, Qwen3-4B, Qwen3-8B, Qwen3-14B, and Qwen3-32B [1]. These models support 119 languages and were trained on a vast dataset of nearly 36 trillion tokens, which includes textbooks, question-answer pairs, code snippets, and AI-generated data [1].

The Qwen3 models have been optimized for reasoning and quick response capabilities. They were further enhanced through reinforcement learning across over 20 general-domain tasks, improving their ability to follow instructions, adhere to formats, and demonstrate agent-like behaviors [1]. Notably, the largest public Qwen3 model, Qwen3-32B, is competitive with other proprietary and open AI models, such as DeepSeek‚Äôs R1 and surpasses OpenAI's o1 model in several benchmarks [1].

For deployment, users can leverage frameworks like SGLang and vLLM for deployment, while tools such as Ollama, LMStudio, MLX, llama.cpp, and KTransformers are recommended for local usage [1]. The models are available under the Apache 2.0 license and can be accessed via platforms like Hugging Face, ModelScope, and Kaggle [1].

Chinese tech company Alibaba on Monday released Qwen3, a family of AI models the company claims matches and in some cases outperforms the best models available from Google and OpenAI.
Most of the models are ‚Äî or soon will be ‚Äî available for download under an ‚Äúopen‚Äù license from AI dev platform Hugging Face and GitHub. They range in size from 0.6 billion parameters to 235 billion parameters. Parameters roughly correspond to a model‚Äôs problem-solving skills, and models with more parameters generally perform better than those with fewer parameters.








The rise of China-originated model series like Qwen have increased the pressure on American labs such as OpenAI to deliver more capable AI technologies. They‚Äôve also led policymakers to implement restrictions aimed at limiting the ability of Chinese AI companies to obtain the chips necessary to train models.

The Qwen3 models support 119 languages, Alibaba says, and were trained on a dataset of nearly 36 trillion tokens. Tokens are the raw bits of data that a model processes; 1 million tokens is equivalent to about 750,000 words. Alibaba says that Qwen3 was trained on a combination of textbooks, ‚Äúquestion-answer pairs,‚Äù code snippets, AI-generated data, and more.
These improvements, along with others, greatly boosted Qwen3‚Äôs capabilities compared to its predecessor, Qwen2, says Alibaba. None of the Qwen3 models are head and shoulders above top-of-the-line recent models like OpenAI‚Äôs o3 and o4-mini, but they‚Äôre strong performers nonetheless.
On Codeforces, a platform for programming contests, the largest Qwen3 model ‚Äî Qwen-3-235B-A22B ‚Äî just beats out OpenAI‚Äôs o3-mini and Google‚Äôs Gemini 2.5 Pro. Qwen-3-235B-A22B also bests o3-mini on the latest version of AIME, a challenging math benchmark, and BFCL, a test for assessing a model‚Äôs ability to ‚Äúreason‚Äù about problems.

> Need to check if there's a specific example in the sources. In source [1], there's code that uses MCPServerStdio with commands like 'uvx' and arguments for time and fetch servers. Also, the example uses the qwen.py script which sets up the agent with specific MCP servers.
> 
> So, putting it all together: import necessary modules, configure the LLM model with the right parameters, define the MCP servers using MCPServerStdio, and then create the Agent instance. The script should allow the user to run queries through the agent that interacts with MCP servers.
</details>
Here's a Python script to access MCP servers using **Qwen3** as the LLM backend. This example uses `pydantic-ai` and integrates with MCP servers like `mcp-server-time` and `mcp-server-fetch`, as shown in the context [1]:

```python
import os
from pydantic_ai import Agent
from pydantic_ai.models.openai import OpenAIModel
from pydantic_ai.providers.openai import OpenAIProvider
from pydantic_ai.mcp import MCPServerStdio

# --- 1. Configure the LLM backend (Qwen3) ---
llm = OpenAIModel(
    model_name="qwen3:30b",  # Use the correct model tag
    provider=OpenAIProvider(
        base_url="http://localhost:11434/v1",  # Ollama or proxy URL
    ),
)

# --- 2. Define MCP servers to use ---
mcp_servers = [
    MCPServerStdio(
        command="uvx",  # Use the correct executable (e.g., `npx` or `uvx`)
        args=["mcp-server-time", "--local-timezone=Asia/Shanghai"]
    ),
    MCPServerStdio(
        command="uvx",
        args=["mcp-server-fetch"]
    ),
]

# --- 3. Create the Agent ---
agent = Agent(
    model=llm,
    mcp_servers=mcp_servers,
    system_message="You are a helpful assistant. Use MCP tools for accurate answers."
)

# --- 4. Define a function to run queries ---
def ask(query: str):
    async def run():
        async with agent.run_mcp_servers():
            result = await agent.run(query)
            print(result.output)

    anyio.run(run)

# Example usage
ask("What time is it in Shanghai and what's the weather there?")
```

---

### Key Notes:
1. **LLM Backend**: The script assumes Qwen3 is served via Ollama (`http://localhost:11424/v1`) or a proxy. Adjust the `base_url` and `model_name` as needed.
2. **MCP Servers**: The example uses `mcp-server-time` and `mcp-server-fetch`. Replace these with other servers (e.g., `@modelcontextprotocol/server-brave-search`) as needed [1].
3. **Dependencies**: Install required packages:
   ```bash
   pip install pydantic-ai-slim[mcp,streaming] mcp anyio
   ```
4. **Runtime**: Ensure `uvx` or `npx` is available in your environment to launch MCP servers [1].

For advanced use, you can extend this with tools like `code_interpreter` or integrate with Claude Desktop [1]. Let me know if you need help deploying specific servers!

Integrate MCP Servers in Python LLM Code

the CodeThe following code sample is an adaptation of the MCP quickstart documentation where we replace Claude Desktop with a Python script and OpenAI API for the LLM. For more detailed guidance, refer to the official documentation.

What is MCP?
The Model Context Protocol (MCP) lets you build servers that expose data and functionality to LLM applications in a secure, standardized way. Think of it like a web API, but specifically designed for LLM interactions. MCP servers can:

Expose data through Resources (think of these sort of like GET endpoints; they are used to load information into the LLM's context)
Provide functionality through Tools (sort of like POST endpoints; they are used to execute code or otherwise produce a side effect)
Define interaction patterns through Prompts (reusable templates for LLM interactions)
And more!

Build with Qwen3
Tool Use
For tool use capabilities, we recommend taking a look at Qwen-Agent, which provides a wrapper around these APIs to support tool use or function calling with MCP support.
Tool use with Qwen3 can also be conducted with SGLang, vLLM,  Transformers, llama.cpp, Ollama, etc.
Follow guides in our documentation to see how to enable the support.
Finetuning
We advise you to use training frameworks, including Axolotl, unsloth, Swift, Llama-Factory, etc., to finetune your models with SFT, DPO, GRPO, etc.
License Agreement
All our open-source models are licensed under Apache 2.0.
You can find the license files in the respective Hugging Face repositories.
Citation

LMStudio
Qwen3 has already been supported by lmstudio.ai. You can directly use LMStudio with our GGUF files.
MLX-LM
If you are running on Apple Silicon, mlx-lm also supports Qwen3 (mlx-lm>=0.24.0).
Look for models ending with MLX on HuggingFace Hub.
Deploy Qwen3
Qwen3 is supported by multiple inference frameworks.
Here we demonstrate the usage of SGLang and vLLM.
You can also find Qwen3 models from various inference providers, e.g., Alibaba Cloud Model Studio.
SGLang
SGLang is a fast serving framework for large language models and vision language models.
SGLang could be used to launch a server with OpenAI-compatible API service.
sglang>=0.4.6.post1 is required.
It is as easy as
python -m sglang.launch_server --model-path Qwen/Qwen3-8B --port 30000 --reasoning-parser qwen3
An OpenAI-compatible API will be available at http://localhost:30000/v1.
vLLM
vLLM is a high-throughput and memory-efficient inference and serving engine for LLMs.
vllm>=0.8.4 is required.

ImportantQwen3 models adopt a different naming scheme.
The post-trained models do not use the "-Instruct" suffix any more. For example, Qwen3-32B is the newer version of Qwen2.5-32B-Instruct.
The base models now have names ending with "-Base".

# --- Step 4: Define Function to Run Queries ---
def ask(query: str):
    async def run():
        try:
            # Start MCP servers in the background
            async with agent.run_mcp_servers():
                result = await agent.run(query)
                print(f"‚úÖ Result: {result.output}")
        except Exception as e:
            print(f"‚ùå Error: {e}")

    # Run the async function
    anyio.run(run)

# --- Example Usage ---
ask("What time is it in Shanghai and what's the weather there?")
```

---

### **4. Key Notes for Implementation**  
#### **A. Dependencies Installation**  
Install the required Python packages:  
```bash
pip install pydantic-ai-slim[mcp,streaming] mcp anyio uvx
```
- `pydantic-ai-slim`: Lightweight framework for LLM agents.  
- `mcp`: Model Context Protocol library for server communication.  
- `anyio`: Asynchronous I/O support for Python.  
- `uvx`: Tool to launch MCP servers (install via `npm install -g uvx` if not already present).  

#### **B. MCP Server Setup**  
- Ensure `mcp-server-time` and `mcp-server-fetch` are installed. Use `uvx` or `npx`:  
  ```bash
  uvx install mcp-server-time
  uvx install mcp-server-fetch
  ```
- Alternatively, use `npx`:  
  ```bash
  npx mcp-server-time@latest
  npx mcp-server-fetch@latest
  ```

#### **C. Qwen3 Backend Setup**  
- If using Ollama: Ensure `qwen3:30b` is available via `ollama run qwen3`.  
- If using a proxy: Replace `http://localhost:11434/v1` with your backend URL.  

#### **D. Troubleshooting**  
- **Error: MCP Server Not Found**: Verify `uvx` or `npx` is installed and servers are correctly configured.  
- **Error: Model Not Found**: Confirm `qwen3:30b` is available via Ollama or your proxy.  
- **Asynchronous Execution**: Ensure `anyio` is properly installed and the script runs in an async environment.  

---

### **5. Advanced Use Cases**  
- **Extend with Code Interpreter**: Add `code_interpreter` for executing Python code.  
- **Integrate with Claude Desktop**: Use `@modelcontextprotocol/server-brave-search` for web searches.  
- **Add More Servers**: Replace `mcp-server-time` and `mcp-server-fetch` with other tools (e.g., `@modelcontextprotocol/server-brave-search`, `mcp-server-calc` for math).  

---

### **6. Final Notes**  
This script demonstrates how to combine Qwen3 with MCP servers for real-time queries. If you encounter issues, check:  
1. **Server Installation**: Ensure `uvx` or `npx` is used to install MCP servers.  
2. **LLM Backend**: Confirm Qwen3 is accessible via the specified URL.  
3. **Permissions**: Ensure your environment allows launching servers and accessing external tools.  

Let me know if you need help deploying specific servers or troubleshooting errors!

<source id=" 1 ">The Open WebUI is a self-hosted, open-source web interface for LLMs. It provides an intuitive and user-friendly experience to manage models, chat with them, and customize their behavior. The interface supports multiple backends such as Ollama, LMStudio, and other OpenAI-compatible APIs. It allows users to create custom models using a Modelfile, which defines the model‚Äôs behavior and system prompts. The interface also includes features like document management for Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG), user authentication, and API key management. Open WebUI is designed to be flexible, allowing users to deploy it with Docker or directly via Python. It's particularly useful for those who want a centralized platform to manage and interact with various LLMs without needing complex configurations [1].</source>


To install and run Open WebUI on Windows localhost, follow these steps:

1. **Install Ollama**: Download and install Ollama from [ollama.com](https://ollama.com). Once installed, you can pull models using the command `ollama pull modelname` [1].

2. **Install Open WebUI**:
   - Using Docker: Run the following command in your terminal:
     ```
     docker run -d -p 3000:8080 --add-host=host.docker.internal:host-gateway -v open-webui:/app/backend/data --name open-webui --restart always ghcr.io/open-webui/open-webui:main
     ```
   - Alternatively, you can install Open WebUI using Python:
     ```
     pip install open-webui
     open-webui serve
     ```

3. **Access Open WebUI**: Open your browser and navigate to `http://localhost:3000` [1].

4. **Configure LLM Providers**: After logging in, go to Settings ‚Üí Connections and add your API keys for the services you want to use. Open WebUI supports any OpenAI-compatible endpoints [1].

5. **Manage Models**: You can manage models through the admin console by navigating to Settings ‚Üí Models and toggling the activation switch next to each model name [1].

For more detailed information, refer to the official Open WebUI documentation.

But when things don‚Äôt work as expected (e.g., the model "hallucinates" or misses relevant info), it's often not the model's fault‚Äîit's a context issue.
Let‚Äôs break down the common causes and solutions so you can supercharge your RAG accuracy! üöÄ

Navigate to: Admin Settings > Documents.
Make sure you're using a robust content extraction engine such as:

Apache Tika
Docling
Custom extractors (depending on your document types)



üìå Tip: Try uploading a document and preview the extracted content. If it‚Äôs blank or missing key sections, you need to adjust your extractor settings or use a different engine.

2. Only a Small Part of the Document is Being Used üìÑ‚û°Ô∏è‚úÇÔ∏è‚Äã
Open WebUI is designed to work with models that have limited context windows by default. For instance, many local models (e.g. Ollama's default models) are limited to 2048 tokens. Because of this, Open WebUI aggressively trims down the retrieved content to fit within the assumed available space.
‚úÖ Solutions:

Go to Admin Settings > Documents
Either:

üí° Enable ‚ÄúBypass Embedding and Retrieval‚Äù ‚Äî This sends full content directly without applying strict retrieval filters.
üîç Toggle on ‚ÄúFull Context Mode‚Äù ‚Äî This injects more comprehensive content into the model prompt.

My question is inside of open-webui how can I use their tools and function calling features? Give me examples of how I can make a qwen3 model execute python code or apply a diff patch to a file.

Since the user mentioned a diff patch, maybe using the code execution tool to run commands like git apply or patch. However, Open WebUI's code execution is sandboxed with gVisor, so direct file system access might be restricted. But the user can use the code execution tool to generate a diff and apply it, assuming they have the necessary permissions.
> 
> I should also check if there are any limitations. The context mentioned that code execution is sandboxed, so the user needs to be aware of security restrictions. Also, using tools like 'Run code' requires enabling them per model.
> 
> I need to structure the answer step-by-step, first explaining how to set up code execution with Qwen3 in Open WebUI, then providing an example of executing Python code. Then move on to applying a diff patch, explaining the process and possible limitations.
> 
> Make sure to reference the context where applicable. For example, when talking about code execution tools, cite the source that explains adding tools to Open WebUI. Also, mention the sandboxing aspect from earlier context.
> 
> Check if there's any confusion in the user's question. They mentioned Qwen3, but Open WebUI typically uses Ollama models. However, the user might be using a different setup where Qwen3 is integrated via Ollama or another backend. Need to clarify that if the model isn't available, they should pull it first.
> 
> Also, ensure that the examples are clear and actionable. For the diff patch example, maybe suggest using the code execution tool to generate a diff or apply it if possible within the sandboxed environment.
> 
> Finally, summarize the steps and mention any prerequisites like installing necessary tools or ensuring models are available.
</details>
To use **tools** and **function calling features** in Open WebUI with the Qwen3 model, follow these steps. This includes executing Python code and applying diff patches to files (with caveats about sandboxing).

---

### **1. Enable Code Execution in Open WebUI**
Open WebUI supports code execution via a sandboxed environment (gVisor) for security. To use it with Qwen3:

#### **Step 1: Install the Code Execution Tool**
- Go to **Workspace ‚Üí Tools** in Open WebUI.
- Click **+ Add Tool** and input:
  - **Toolkit Name**: `Run code`
  - **Description**: "Run arbitrary code safely in a gVisor sandbox."
  - Replace the code section with `open-webui/tools/run_code.py` (ensure this file exists).
  - Click **Save**.

#### **Step 2: Enable the Tool for Qwen3**
- Go to **Workspace ‚Üí Models**.
- Find your Qwen3 model and click the pencil (‚úèÔ∏è) icon.
- Under **Tools**, check the box for `Run code`.
- Click **Save & Update**.

---

### **2. Example: Execute Python Code with Qwen3**
Once enabled, you can prompt Qwen3 to execute code:

#### **Prompt Example**:
> "Run a Python script that calculates the sum of numbers from 1 to 10."

#### **How It Works**:
- Qwen3 generates the code (e.g., `sum(range(1, 11))`).
- You click the **Run code** button in Open WebUI (if enabled as a tool).
- The output appears in the UI.

#### **Code Execution via Tool**:
You can also define a custom tool (e.g., `check_system_status`) as shown in the context [1], which is triggered by a system prompt:
```python
class Tools:
    def check_system_status():
        print("‚úÖ System status: Active")
        return "System status: Active"
```
- This function is registered in Open WebUI and can be invoked by Qwen3 via the tool system.

---

### **3. Example: Apply a Diff Patch to a File**
Applying diff patches requires direct file system access, which is **sandboxed** in Open WebUI. However, you can use the `Run code` tool to simulate this:

#### **Step 1: Generate a Diff Patch**
Prompt Qwen3 to generate a diff (e.g., for a file `example.txt`):
```python
# Example: Create a diff patch (hypothetical scenario)
import difflib

original = "Hello, world!\n"
modified = "Hello, Open WebUI!\n"

diff = difflib.unified_diff(original.splitlines(), modified.splitlines())
print("\n".join(diff))
```

#### **Step 2: Apply the Diff (Limited Scope)**
- Open WebUI‚Äôs code execution is sandboxed, so **direct file system access** (e.g., `patch` or `git apply`) is restricted.
- If your use case allows, you can:
  - Use the `Run code` tool to generate diffs.
  - Manually apply patches in a local environment outside the sandbox.

#### **Workaround for Sandboxed Environments**:
If you must apply patches within Open WebUI, use the `run_code.py` tool to write files to a sandboxed directory (e.g., `/tmp/`). Example:
```python
with open("/tmp/example.txt", "w") as f:
    f.write("Hello, Open WebUI!\n")
```

---

### **4. Key Limitations**
- **Sandboxing**: Open WebUI‚Äôs code execution is restricted to a gVisor sandbox. Direct file system access (e.g., modifying files outside `/tmp/`) is not allowed.
- **Tool Compatibility**: Ensure the Qwen3 model supports function calling via Open WebUI‚Äôs tool system. If not, use system prompts to trigger code execution.

---

### **5. Summary**
- Use Open WebUI‚Äôs `Run code` tool to execute Python scripts with Qwen3.
- For diff patches, generate diffs via code execution and apply them manually or within the sandboxed environment.
- Ensure tools are enabled for your Qwen3 model and verify compatibility with Open WebUI‚Äôs sandboxed execution.

For further details, refer to the [Open WebUI documentation](https://github.com/open-webui/open-webui) or check the context [1] for tool configuration steps.

Overview‚Äã
Open WebUI allows for the client-side execution of Python code in the browser, utilizing Pyodide to run scripts within a code block in a chat. This feature enables Large Language Models (LLMs) to generate Python scripts that can be executed directly in the browser, leveraging a range of libraries supported by Pyodide.

To maintain user privacy and flexibility, Open WebUI mirrors PyPI packages, avoiding direct external network requests. This approach also enables the use of Pyodide in environments without internet access.
The Open WebUI frontend includes a self-contained WASM (WebAssembly) Python environment, powered by Pyodide, which can execute basic Python scripts generated by LLMs. This environment is designed for ease of use, requiring no additional setup or installation.

import os

      "args": ["mcp-server-time"]
    }
  }
}
''')

# Step 8: Run the server
print("Project setup complete. Running the MCP server...")
subprocess.run(["uv", "run", "main.py"], check=True)

   - Creates a `main.py` file to run the server.
   - Sets up an `mcp_settings.json` file to configure the MCP server with `mcp-server-time`.

5. **Execution**:
   - Runs the server using `uv run main.py`.

### **Next Steps**
- Ensure `uv` and `uvx` are installed on your system.
- The script assumes a Unix-like environment (Linux/macOS). For Windows, adjust the activation command.
- The `mcp-server-time` tool must be installed. If not, install it using:

  ```

What‚Äôs an MCP Tool?

An MCP tool is a Python function you register with your MCP server that the AI can call when it needs to take action‚Äîlike reading a file, querying an API, or performing a calculation.
To register a tool, you decorate the function with @mcp.tool(). Behind the scenes, MCP generates a definition that the AI can see and interact with.
But before we do that, let‚Äôs follow a best practice: we‚Äôll define our MCP server instance in one central place, then import it into each file that defines tools. This ensures everything stays clean and consistent.



  Step 1: Define the MCP Server Instance

Open your server.py and main.py files (or create it if you haven‚Äôt already), and add the following:


# server.py

from mcp.server.fastmcp import FastMCP

# This is the shared MCP server instance
mcp = FastMCP("mix_server")

  Step 4: Add Required Dependencies

We‚Äôre going to install three key packages:

mcp[cli]: The official MCP SDK and command-line tools

pyarrow: Adds support for reading Parquet files via Pandas

Install them using:

Let‚Äôs take a moment to review what you‚Äôve accomplished.



  What You Built

By following this guide, you now have a fully working MCP server that:

Uses Python and the official mcp SDK
Reads real data from both CSV and Parquet files

Follows a clean, modular folder structure

# Create a new project
uv init documentation

# Navigate to the project directory
cd documentation

# Create a virtual environment
uv venv

# Activate the virtual environment
# On Windows:
.venv\Scripts\activate
# On macOS/Linux:
source .venv/bin/activate


Step 2: Install Dependencies
Install the necessary packages:

uv pip install mcp-server httpx beautifulsoup4 python-dotenv


Step 3: Create Environment Variables
Create a .env file in your project directory to store your Serper API key:

SERPER_API_KEY=your_serper_api_key_here


Building the MCP Server
Now, let‚Äôs build our MCP server. Create a new file called main.py in your project directory:
Step 1: Import Required Libraries

import os
import json
import httpx
import asyncio
from bs4 import BeautifulSoup
from dotenv import load_dotenv
from mcp_server import fast_mcp

# Load environment variables
load_dotenv()


Step 2: Define Constants

claude mcp add


This will start an interactive prompt to configure your MCP server:

Enter a name for your server (e.g., ‚Äúdocs‚Äù).
Select the local project.
Enter the command to start your MCP server, which is the full path to your UV executable followed by run main.py.
Enter the working directory, which is the full path to your project directory.
Leave the environment variables empty if you‚Äôre using a .env file.
Confirm the configuration.

Step 2: Verify the MCP Server
To verify that your MCP server is added correctly, run:

claude mcp list


You should see your ‚Äúdocs‚Äù server in the list.
Step 3: Test the MCP Server with Claude Code
Run Claude Code and ask it a question that would benefit from access to up-to-date documentation:

claude code


Then, ask Claude:

Create a new function that implements a ChromaDB database with LangChain and make sure to use the latest integration.

Integrating with Claude Desktop
Step 1: Open Claude Desktop Settings

Open Claude Desktop.
Click on ‚ÄúSettings‚Äù in the bottom left corner.
Click on ‚ÄúDeveloper‚Äù and then ‚ÄúEdit Configuration‚Äù.

Step 2: Add MCP Server Configuration
In the configuration file, add your MCP server under the mcpServers section:

{
  "mcpServers": [
    {
      "command": "/full/path/to/uv",
      "args": ["run", "main.py"],
      "cwd": "/full/path/to/your/documentation/directory"
    }
  ]
}


Replace /full/path/to/uv with the full path to your UV executable and /full/path/to/your/documentation/directory with the full path to your project directory.
To find the full path to your UV executable, you can use:

On Windows: where uv
On macOS/Linux: which uv
